intro: Cuviera subuliflora, commonly known as the narrow-leaved cupuaçu, is a member of the Malvaceae family and is native to the Amazon rainforest. It is characterized by its small, lance-shaped leaves and produces yellowish flowers that are typically clustered in inflorescences. The plant thrives in humid, tropical climates and requires well-drained, nutrient-rich soil. Its fruit, which resembles a large, elongated pod, contains a sweet, creamy pulp used in various food products. Due to its ecological importance and potential economic value, it is often cultivated in agroforestry systems in its native habitat.
